body:
Here is the code I used for testing. If the existing test case is correct, then there is something wrong with mxnet import. And I also used a pre-train model for testing, but the output is garbage. I assume the shape was mess up somewhere.

```
data = mx.sym.var('data')
sym = mx.sym.Convolution(data, dilate=(1, 1), kernel=(4, 5), no_bias=False, num_filter=64, num_group=1, pad=[1, 1], stride=(1, 1), layout='NHWC')

arg_params = {}
aux_params = {}

dtype = 'float16'
input_shape = (1, 720, 1280, 3)

shape_dict = {'data': input_shape}
mod, params = relay.frontend.from_mxnet(sym, shape_dict, dtype, arg_params, aux_params)

func = mod["main"]

target = tvm.target.create('cuda -libs=cudnn')
with relay.build_config(opt_level=3):
    graph, lib, params = relay.build(func, target, params=params)

ctx = tvm.gpu(0)
x = np.ones(input_shape).astype(dtype)

m = graph_runtime.create(graph, lib, ctx)
m.set_input(input_name, tvm.nd.array(x))
m.set_input(**params)

m.run()
tvm_output = m.get_output(0)
print(tvm_output.shape)
```

I figured out the issue I was running into, which I believe is a regression in relay, so I've opened a separate issue detailing it here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-tvm/issues/4534#issue-539162046

After increasing my ulimit, the following works with VM:

```python
mod = relay.Module.from_expr(relay.transform.gradient(loss_func))
seq = relay.transform.Sequential(
    [relay.transform.PartialEvaluate(), relay.transform.DeadCodeElimination()]
)
with relay.build_config(opt_level=3):
    mod = seq(mod)

exec = relay.create_executor(kind="vm", mod=mod)
loss, grads = exec.evaluate()(label, data, *params)
```

It would be useful to add this information to the relay documentation about running higher order gradient functions in the VM

@yongwww

Have you managed to get `onnx.checker.check_model` to work with ONNX 1.6? Whenever I've tried updating I encounter frequent segmentation faults. This is a known bug with 1.6 as seen in [this Onnx issue](https://github.com/onnx/onnx/issues/2394). Assuming it still is around, we either have to drop use of the model checker (which is probably fine since it's not essential) or wait until they fix it in 1.7. If you want to go with the former, you should include the removal of the checker with this PR.
LGTM, thanks for improving this schedule!
You're not doing anything wrong. Not supporting NHWC layouts on Arm CPUs is a known issue and something we should have patched in soon.

With ONNX v1.6, I do get segfault when importing both ONNX and PyTorch (seems to be the same issue as [this one](https://github.com/onnx/onnx/issues/1331)). If I remove PyTorch import, my test case in #4536, which uses onnxruntime (which in tern calls check_model) works fine. The following works for me too.
```
import onnx
model = onnx.load("resnet50.onnx") 
onnx.checker.check_model(model)
```

Doesn't the CI = green mean we are good to go with v1.6? Assuming the CI is updated with this PR and is running on v1.6 (not sure the correct way to update the CI env)

I think even if NHWC isn't supported, the auto-tuning shouldn't fail as a result. We can still compile networks that are initially in NHWC format as AlterOpLayout converts them to NCHW. I think AutoTVM should also do this instead of just failing.

AutoTVM does not compile the model but just tune the ops extracted from the model. Accordingly, failing when the ops are not supported for tuning is reasonable.

Also please open such discussion topics in [discuss](https://discuss.tvm.ai/).
Thanks @icemelon9

It doesn't compile, but it does run optimize which should invoke the appropriate passes to transform the graph. Is it a design choice for AutoTVM not to apply this pass? If so I'm happy to open a discuss post, as this is quite unintuitive behaviour.

The CI is not directly updated when the docker get updated, see https://docs.tvm.ai/contribute/pull_request.html#ci-environment . Would be great if we can have tests to confirm things, i will also followup later this week.
Thanks @mbarrett97
Running tests/python/frontend/onnx/test_forward.py with the new CI should confirm whether ONNX v1.6 is in good state. Based on the discussion so far, it seems likely to crash.

@abergeron I tested locally and it looks good to me. If your code is not called, this is likely generic func has been registered for other targets. For example, in llvm target, `x86/conv2d_transpose` will be called instead of `nn/conv2d_transpose`. Could you rebase so that we can get this in?
Not sure if that workaround works for all cases, but you are welcome to open an RFC to collect opinions from others.
@tqchen @zhiics Please help to review it again.

Hi @optima2005 , @masahi ,
I am new to tvm community. I was trying to implement maxpool3d operator based on reference implementation from tensorflow(r=1.14) into tvm codebase. For testing the same, I have written relay and topi test cases. I am also writing test cases in test_forward.py(for tensorflow) which compares tvm output with tensorflow output. I want to know is there any specific reason why you have not added any changes in test_forward.py(comparing tvm with tf) for unit testing?? Should i ignore this file altogether?

Hi @optima2005 , @masahi ,
I am new to tvm community. I was trying to implement maxpool3d operator based on reference implementation from tensorflow(r=1.14) into tvm codebase. For testing the same, I have written relay and topi test cases. I am also writing test cases in test_forward.py(for tensorflow) which compares tvm output with tensorflow output. I want to know is there any specific reason why you have not added any changes in test_forward.py(comparing tvm with tf) for unit testing?? Should i ignore this file altogether?

Best Regards,
Deepak Babel

Hi, @deepakbabel
This PR is just to implement a 3d pooling(max&avg) operation for relay, not including the TF frontend, which is to transform the 3d pooling operation in TF model into TVM relay operation.

Hi @optima2005 ,
Thank you for clarifying this. I want to support TF frontend in TVM for this operator(maxpool3d), so that I can compile a TF model using TVM. I am trying to ascertain changes required in TVM front-end specific files like test_forward.py and tensorflow.py file. As of now these files have support only for 2D image data format("NCHW"). Looks like there would be some small design change to include 3D("NCDHW") or nD dimension data. Do you happen to have any inputs/suggestions on the same.

@optima2005 - 
Here are the path of the files that I am referring to:
tvm/tests/python/frontend/tensorflow/test_forward.py
tvm/python/tvm/relay/frontend/tensorflow.py

Best Regards,
Deepak Babel
cc @Laurawly @Hzfengsy @vinx13 @tqchen

@deepakbabel, If I would implement 3D pooling TF frontend, I would create a new function by following the current 2D pooling [function](https://github.com/apache/incubator-tvm/blob/5d328c5c8c588bb0a7b42cebefea5a835f3977fe/python/tvm/relay/frontend/tensorflow.py#L125). And add it to the converting [map](https://github.com/apache/incubator-tvm/blob/5d328c5c8c588bb0a7b42cebefea5a835f3977fe/python/tvm/relay/frontend/tensorflow.py#L1402) for TF 3D pooling transformation.  By this approach, the original 2d pooling won't be impacted and we won't handle too much conditionals in one function.
I will suggest we wait until onnxrt 1.7 then as per suggested by @jwfromm @masahi shall we close for now?
also cc  @Hzfengsy @masahi @kazum

It would be great if we can clarify further, as the ATLNR java package is only used to generate the parser, and the parser itself depends on antlr runtime of the corresponding language(in this case python) but does not depend on the ANTLR java

NOTE that we started with ANTLR python for simplicity, we could in theory move over to ATNLR c++ runtime, which will get around the issue altogether. Would be great if we can get an assessment of feasibility. cc @jroesch
@tobegit3hub please fix the lint error. @soiferj @jwfromm @zhiics @FrozenGene would be great if you can help review this pr

Ok, no problem for me.

@kaimast if you look at how tests are run, you should use limit to [`--test-threads=1`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-tvm/blob/master/tests/scripts/task_rust.sh#L63) because the default registered global functions are not accessible in a multi-threaded way. There's no requirement of python binding installed for testing the rust frontend, only if you want to run the resnet example.
cc @junrushao1994
Is there any use case that this is performance critical?
don't know, it was a short fix that is simple enough that I feel worth the change, always good to make the code a bit faster :)
It looks good. Btw in mnm, we treat all dtypes/ctx as strings for convenience. I think packed function has been able to deal with string dtypes, and some time it is worthwhile to do it to ctx as well

I've tested on an environment with ONNX 1.6 + PyTorch master build, I can run onnx/test_forward.py without any issue. I recommend updating our CI env to PyTorch 1.4 (which should be out soon) along with ONNX 1.7.
